commit_message:
Add a common test case for Port Binding Extension

This commit merges the test cases for Port Binding Extension in
Linux Bridge plugin and Open vSwitch plugin into a common one.
It makes it easier for each plugin to support the port binding extension.

This commit also adds binding:capabilities attribute to OVS plugin.
Note that binding:capabilities is under discussion and it may be changed
in the future. This change is done just to make OVS plugin support
same as Linux Bridge plugin and pass the common unit test for the extension.

blueprint vif-plugging-improvements

Change-Id: Idc38ea65fe2059e23814d94cd0a0f11a09d1f43e

commit_message:
Don't inherit from base.html in 500 error page

For server errors, the context passed to the template is empty,
so things like STATIC_URL and context processors don't work.

Fixes bug 1067206 for the folsom branch.

This has been adapted to folsom release and is a backport from master.

Change-Id: I5cd60523360d71b088226e4d0f87d88bac8a8df3

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-16 15:56:11.000000000', 'message': 'ThreadGroup remove unused name parameters

Thread/ThreadGroup constructors take a name parameter which is never
used, so we can simplify things a bit by removing it.  If anything is
referencing the internal self.name it should be using its own
name->threadgroup mapping (e.g via a dict or similar container class)

Change-Id: I6877a2fcee60ce9fc087d38aa492d7c9d50ce97e
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
ThreadGroup remove unused name parameters

Thread/ThreadGroup constructors take a name parameter which is never
used, so we can simplify things a bit by removing it.  If anything is
referencing the internal self.name it should be using its own
name->threadgroup mapping (e.g via a dict or similar container class)

Change-Id: I6877a2fcee60ce9fc087d38aa492d7c9d50ce97e
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Command to reset quota values to defaults

A new command quota-reset added to the nova which resets
the quota values of specified tenant, to the default.

Fixes bug 1064854

Change-Id: I3a2aff57d1deb18ed448737ba6052438a91ddfd1

subject: Add host to instance_faults table.
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-01-17 20:50:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I like the patch, but why use host over something like the service id? Since multiple services can run on one host, that might provide some extra information on what service created the exception. Also, we have had problems with instance['host'] being accurate in the past and service id is much less likely to be inaccurate"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-01-17 20:55:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I like the patch, but why use host over something like the service id? 

I used `host` because we already store that with the instance and that's what I was using to troubleshoot some reason bugs. With a service_id, it'd be another level of indirection, no? I'd have to map that to an ip address.

> Since multiple services can run on one host, that might provide some extra information on what service created the exception. 

Storing `host` and `service_id` might not be a bad idea actually.

> Also, we have had problems with instance['host'] being accurate in the past and service id is much less likely to be inaccurate

I'm not familiar with this; why was `host` inaccurate? Wouldn't that be a major configuration issue?"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-01-17 20:55:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

s/reason/recent/'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-01-17 21:03:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-01-17 21:07:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Don't you want CONF.host instead of instance['host']...  if you want to know what host generated the fault?

Johannes: service_id will be hard to get at, unless it's a global, I think.  But if we had access to that, i'd probably propose we use service['host'] and service['topic'] instead of the ID."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-01-17 21:10:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Chris: Yeah, I *think* the way it's being called CONF.host == instance['host']; but I don't mind changing it to CONF.host to make it even clearer.

I think having add_instance_fault take an `instance` obj instead of uuid is more flexible, so I'd vote to keep that refactoring in place even though it won't be relevant to this particular patch w/ that change."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-01-17 21:14:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Agree on passing instance.  Can be useful to avoid future work.  I think that you may be correct in most cases when the faults come from compute on CONF.host == instance['host'].... except there could be a fault when you're migrating an instance and the destination creates a fault before instance['host'] is updated.  Or the source creates a fault after instance['host'] is updated... etc.   Also, the scheduler could fault without having scheduled the instance to a host yet."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-01-17 21:15:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Chris beat me to it about instance['host']. So everything he said :)"}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-01-17 21:16:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This is a good idea.

My one concern is instance['host'] will not always be set where we generate instance faults.  The scheduler can generate faults and instance['host'] will be None at that time.  

Ideally we'd store the service_id as Johannes said, but it's self.host (CONF.host) is definitely more accessible and would concisely state which host the fault came from.

Thanks for doing this!"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-01-17 21:22:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

To clarify my earlier messages, if getting service_id is a pain in the ass, then only storing the host is fine with me. It shouldn't be hard to figure out which service generated the fault from looking at the traceback.

However, I would prefer to use CONF.host to ensure that it's accurate for all of the reasons Chris and Brian outlined."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-17 21:27:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

commit_message:
Add host to instance_faults table.

Instances can be rescheduled or migrated to different hosts; so, to make
troubleshooting easier, it's convenient to store the host in which the
failure occured with the instance fault record.

Change-Id: Ib2b9a5bab5d95739b730f0eab15884c2db33a782

commit_message:
Support for SSL in wsgi.Server

SSL are entirely optional. Support for SSL as well using code from glance. We
have some new options for configuring the SSL support. There are tests for
accessing a sample app w/o ipv6 or ssl, one with just ssl and one with
ipv6 and ssl

DocImpact

Change-Id: If215198d6fc8219a7de5f7f379cc13f7c797d6ff

[{'created': '2013-01-17 18:16:11.000000000', 'message': "Fix secgroups exercise on postgres

This should fix the failing (but non-voting) postgres gate tests.

Why does postgresql change the value '0.0.0.0/00' to '0.0.0.0/0'?
Clearly the correct value for the network CIDR bits is with only
one zero but even an incorrect value shouldn't be changing.

SQLalchemy is given this for the column:
        Column('cidr', String(length=255)),

Change-Id: Ib19dad23789654664e90518087e5a462fa8b8034
"}]
commit_message:
Fix secgroups exercise on postgres

This should fix the failing (but non-voting) postgres gate tests.

Why does postgresql change the value '0.0.0.0/00' to '0.0.0.0/0'?
Clearly the correct value for the network CIDR bits is with only
one zero but even an incorrect value shouldn't be changing.

SQLalchemy is given this for the column:
        Column('cidr', String(length=255)),

Change-Id: Ib19dad23789654664e90518087e5a462fa8b8034

commit_message:
Check for configured IPV6 before running tests

Some folks don't/can't have IPV6 configured on their systems,
the new IPV6 tests in test_wsgi require that you do, so
let's add a check and skip if there are no IPV6 configured interfaces.

Change-Id: I7cbdcbc3ad4cc4690634f6464d6e28d9f4dfd791

Based on recent changes in Nova, this provides a cleaner/simpler looking config file:

- Move help message before each option, rather than after.
- Print types like "string value" instead of "(StrOpt)"
- Use fewer pound symbols

Switch to a new format that looks much more like a normal config file.

Change-Id: I69f9b7b84215a2a69bdb0c4af9d5e1cb1e105a45
'}]
commit_message:
New cinder.conf.sample format

Based on recent changes in Nova, this provides a cleaner/simpler looking config file:

- Move help message before each option, rather than after.
- Print types like "string value" instead of "(StrOpt)"
- Use fewer pound symbols

Switch to a new format that looks much more like a normal config file.

Change-Id: I69f9b7b84215a2a69bdb0c4af9d5e1cb1e105a45

commit_message:
Fix install_venv-get_distro failure on Fedora

There was no check_exit_code=False used so install_venv died
on Fedora/RHEL/etc.
Also calling external grep command is not neccessary.

Change-Id: I280aed3019b8cb7fce67033158deb34937946fab

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-17 23:51:02.000000000', 'message': 'Use default_notification_level when notification

Fix bug 1089773

Notifications in quantum api do not honor default_notification_level
in quantum.conf and always use INFO level. On the other hand
dhcp-agent refers to default_notification_level.
If default_notification_level is set to a value other than INFO,
dhcp-agent cannot receive notification from quantum server.

Change-Id: Ie3ae576d62e91651aa59b2324ec114716181107f
'}]
commit_message:
Use default_notification_level when notification

Fix bug 1089773

Notifications in quantum api do not honor default_notification_level
in quantum.conf and always use INFO level. On the other hand
dhcp-agent refers to default_notification_level.
If default_notification_level is set to a value other than INFO,
dhcp-agent cannot receive notification from quantum server.

Change-Id: Ie3ae576d62e91651aa59b2324ec114716181107f

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-16 21:33:04.000000000', 'message': 'Call plug_vifs() for all instances in init_host

Remove the assumption that we are using the "flat" networking model
and there is a single bridge interface for all instances on a given
compute node.  Instead simply call plug_vifs() for each instance in
init_host.

Fixes bug 1083784

Change-Id: I4b367deb6851c06c80a4bdf0bd806cf5e867bb0a
(cherry picked from commit 77e38b7cfc2206ef4ac528d3c9faaa09adbf7f58)
'}]
commit_message:
Call plug_vifs() for all instances in init_host

Remove the assumption that we are using the "flat" networking model
and there is a single bridge interface for all instances on a given
compute node.  Instead simply call plug_vifs() for each instance in
init_host.

Fixes bug 1083784

Change-Id: I4b367deb6851c06c80a4bdf0bd806cf5e867bb0a
(cherry picked from commit 77e38b7cfc2206ef4ac528d3c9faaa09adbf7f58)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-14 20:16:14.000000000', 'message': "Fix addition of CPU features when running against legacy libvirt

When running against an libvirt < 0.9.10 which lacks support for the
'host-model' CPU type, we must fake it by copying the host CPU
model and features. Unfortunately the code was forgetting to
append the new features to the CPU object feature list

Bug: 1099527
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 82b55c97d10a55e6a825261397816f6a7ad00fd7)

Change-Id: Ib5e6a173f1ae7d421435af45bf327f5b36c94dd0
"}]
commit_message:
Fix addition of CPU features when running against legacy libvirt

When running against an libvirt < 0.9.10 which lacks support for the
'host-model' CPU type, we must fake it by copying the host CPU
model and features. Unfortunately the code was forgetting to
append the new features to the CPU object feature list

Bug: 1099527
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 82b55c97d10a55e6a825261397816f6a7ad00fd7)

Change-Id: Ib5e6a173f1ae7d421435af45bf327f5b36c94dd0

tempest_coverage.py into the logs directory after a tempest

'}]
commit_message:
Fix tempest coverage report output.

This fixes copying the coverage report generated by
tempest_coverage.py into the logs directory after a tempest
run. Previously there were permissions issues with the script
trying to directly copy it into the logs directory.

Change-Id: Ib9c343057b605d03a60e2536b8ffd5f18374aece

commit_message:
Replace custom tearDown with fixtures and cleanup.

testtools.addCleanup is a more resilient way to perform cleanup activities,
as it will continue to clean things up even if there are unforseen problems.

Specifically, replace custom management of tempdirs with fixtures.TempDir
and replace tearDown methods that can be easily replaced with calls to
addCleanup in the setUp method. There are at least two temp dir creations that
did not have a corresponding cleanup in this patch, which is another reason
for using useFixture(fixtures.TempDir) instead of calls to mkdtemp.

Part of blueprint grizzly-testtools.

Change-Id: I4eb548010612bd5a8d30e8e2304fa66d3d5ffb7c

commit_message:
Create ports in quantum matching hypervisor MAC addresses.

When hypervisors supply a set of MAC addresses for instances, the
network driver is responsible for matching up the requested MACs and
the available (or requested) networks.

The simplest case, which this patch addresses, is to create ports in
quantum on the desired networks, rather than having quantum create
them dynamically with dynamically created MAC addresses.

Change-Id: I84cd96671b76b8beaa31436c8a438f7818ef622f

commit_message:
Only create 1 server for server actions tests.

This switches the setUp() and tearDown() methods in
test_server_actions.py to be setUpClass() and tearDownClass().
The server create and delete for each test method were taking
a significant amount of time. This minimizes the time spent for
those operations by only using one server since there wasn't a
need to use separate servers for each test.

Change-Id: I5e7a3831c9f018e871c0fcfcd575e662a143cd9b

[{'created': '2013-01-17 19:45:41.000000000', 'message': 'Config lockutils to use a temp path for tests.

 * Tests for iptables_manager were leaving lockfiles in the source
   tree due to the default lock path being in the openstack common
   tree.  This patch sets the lock_path option to an empty string
   for unit tests to ensure that a temporary location is used
   instead.

Change-Id: I5d36dca8cfeba991dfe0803e536d3d74dd2ffe7f

commit_message:
Config lockutils to use a temp path for tests.

 * Tests for iptables_manager were leaving lockfiles in the source
   tree due to the default lock path being in the openstack common
   tree.  This patch sets the lock_path option to an empty string
   for unit tests to ensure that a temporary location is used
   instead.

Change-Id: I5d36dca8cfeba991dfe0803e536d3d74dd2ffe7f

subject: use postgresql INET datatype for storing IPs

messages:
[{'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-11-07 16:10:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Postgres's INET datatype offers free validation, some specific operators and most importantly a lot smaller storage size: 7 or 19 bytes (compared to the previous VARCHAR(255)). This could make a difference in the case of bigger deployments. 

The change is specific to postgres, but doesn't add any postgresql specific functionality and keeps everything compatible with the other backends. It does however provide the storage benefit.

It would be great if someone could review the changed tables/columns. I did some test migrations, but I'm not sure if there are any other columns storing IPs which I've missed."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-07 16:29:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-07 18:18:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I really don't like that this brings database specific switches up to the general models.py layer. I think we need to go think about this in more detail as a way to let databases have optimizations below the generic model layer."}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-11-08 10:05:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I don't understand your issue, Sean. This looks good to me since it makes it obvious to the model what columns store an IPAddress as opposed to a string. Then the actual implementation of the IPAddress is underneath the model and database specific. Would you have been happier if I had created a different file to store the IPAddress definition?"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-08 12:57:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

right now nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py has no dialect specific bits in it. I think that should stay that way, because pretty quickly it gets crowded badly with database specific optimizations. Long term I think that's the wrong direction.

There needs to be a more generic solution if we want to support specific db optimizations, hat lets us have model overrides per database."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-08 12:59:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I would also in general get engaged with the nova-db team on approaches like this, the meeting kicked off again last week, and there is a lot of look at various ways to clean up and optimize that layer.

This should also probably be blueprint level material, as I really think this is a bigger conversation on how these kinds of optimizations can be cleanly added.'}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2012-11-12 13:00:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

We use something similar in Moniker[1], So I do like the general idea here..

But - If the core OS projects are going to go down this route, I would love to see the results in oslo/openstack-common instead of duplicated per project!

[1]: https://github.com/stackforge/moniker/blob/master/moniker/storage/impl_sqlalchemy/types.py'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-11-13 17:10:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-11-13 17:15:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-13 17:40:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

Code looks good to me (modulo the necessary rebase; we're up to migration 144 now), but I don't see any response to Sean's comments, and I confess I didn't follow any mailing list discussion that may have been had on this…"}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-11-29 08:28:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Oh, here's the mailing list thread: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-November/002643.html

My plan was to put it in nova first and then try to commit the IPAddress class to oslo-incubator rather than waiting for the class to land in openstack-common first."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-29 18:36:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If we are doing this, then I think looking at the monkier approach is a good one.

First, the migration needs to move forward.

Second, the alternative to pg data type isn't String(255), it's String(39), so there will be a migration for other data stores.

Also, there should be a test case with data for the pg migration. Because this could go wrong enough that it really should be checked. We have special case mysql migration testing for innodb setting in nova/tests/test_migrations.py that could be modified to address something like this."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-11-29 19:07:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Actually, I checked all our existing models for the fields he was changing, and they were all String(255).  While String(39) would probably be more technically correct, using String(255) was proper for this patch.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-30 00:00:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

right, agreed, that models are 255 today, but if we're going to introduce an optimizer for IP address, it's better to do it all at once, not 1 migration for pg and a later one for mysql.

Realistically UUID migration is going to be the one that actually shows a real performance difference. UUIDs as binaries end up way faster than as strings."}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2012-12-28 16:36:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I would prefer to see this change done for both database back ends, and with unit tests for each. I suspect it will be somewhat different for MySQL..."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

commit_message:
Add upload-to-image function to client.

Support uploading a volume to an image in the image service.

Change-Id: Ief996f92aaf6d7a4fee0bce5ca45b92bee3f6990
Fixes: bug #1099866

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/18456/2/check/gate-quantum-python26/2846 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18456/2/check/gate-quantum-python27/2847 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:50:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

I think there are same valuable unit tests here, but also some overlap with test_api_v2.APIv2TestCase.

I suggest either:
1 - move these unit tests to test_api_v2.APIV2TestCase, and remove the duplicated ones
2 - move the filters and fields tests from test_api_v2.APIV2TestCase here, and remove the duplicated ones.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:50:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Salvatore,

I've also looked at APIv2TestCase but it seems more of a quantum.v2.api.router test than quantum.v2.api.base. My intention of this patch is to provide a dedicated test module for quantum.v2.api.base. Let me know if I'm missing something."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:50:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:50:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/18456/3/check/gate-quantum-docs/2468 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18456/3/check/gate-quantum-pep8/3088 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18456/3/check/gate-quantum-python26/2858 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18456/3/check/gate-quantum-python27/2859 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:50:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

My comment was purely from a practical perspective.
I think nobody would ever mind if new unit tests are added.

I see you're scoping these unit tests differently. Correct me If I'm wrong, but you're actually not going through the API engine at all. Your tests merely validate the behaviour of _filters and _fields routines. Which is fine IMO.

Anyway, you're calling this module test_api_v2_base, which becomes confusing when we have test_api_v2 as well (which covers pretty well also base.py). 
I don't want to appear pedant, but if you do not have a good reason for keeping this module separate, perhaps you can just add your test cases to test_api_v2? (I mean adding them as they are, not merging with existing test cases)"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:50:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'd prefer them to be in the same module, or at least rename the new module in a way that clarifies the module is for testing filtering routines.

Said that, I'm not willing on making a strong point here.
If other core reviewers are ok with approving this patch, I'm ok as well!"}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:50:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Salvatore,
Its just that I'm used to having one test file for each module which explicitly runs through all the lines.
We already have test_attributes and test_api_v2_resource so my plan was to separate unittest from test_api_v2 to each module.
But its your call. I'm fine either way."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:50:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Salvatore,

Just to make my self clear, my plan was not to just put unittests related to filters in test_api_v2_base.py. I will write unittests for the Controller class and create_resource() as well.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:50:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:50:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

commit_message:
More unittests for quantum.api.v2.base

Added unittests for the below methods
* quantum.api.v2.base._fields()
* quantum.api.v2.base._filters()
* quantum.api.v2.base.create_resource()

Fixes bug #1092399

Change-Id: Icdddb3a201b4bc577378e78c7a7cd48486a2d57a

commit_message:
Clean up get_instance_id_by_floating_address

Reduce number of nova.db calls in get_instance_id_by_floating_address
to 1, fixed_ip_get_by_floating_address (A new nova.db.api function)

Change-Id: Ie1313ea73290ae11dce03d3726d5c23e4d73cb00

commit_message:
Validated device_name value in block device map

1. Checked value of device_name parameter provided in block device
mapping section of Create server API.
2. Added unit test coverage.

Fixes LP: #1087165

Change-Id: I32ed59a577167d9bf42cb3667bfb1ba3963d6c71

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-16 19:49:05.000000000', 'message': 'enforce server_id can only be uuid or int

the get() function takes an arbitrary id coming from the rest url
for the server. In our current code it checks if this is a proper uuid
and sends it down the uuid path, everything else gets dispatched to
the version that selects by integer id. This means that arbitrary
garbage fuzzed server ids will get sent down the int path, all the way
to the database.

In postgresql, where the db is strongly typed, this causes a type error.
This error was found by tempest nightly runs where we send some 35 and 37
character strings in.

This patch creates and equivalent is_int_like function. If the server_id
is neither uuid_like nor int_like, we throw the InstanceNotFound exception
early. This also saves us a trip to the database in these cases.

Fixes bug #1100253

Change-Id: If4ae8005fd33a23ac50a6408ecd5933a2ff6425c
'}, {'created': '2013-01-16 20:55:54.000000000', 'message': "enforce server_id can only be uuid or int

the get() function takes an arbitrary id coming from the rest url
for the server. In our current code it checks if this is a proper uuid
and sends it down the uuid path, everything else gets dispatched to
the version that selects by integer id. This means that arbitrary
garbage fuzzed server ids will get sent down the int path, all the way
to the database.

In postgresql, where the db is strongly typed, this causes a type error.
This error was found by tempest nightly runs where we send some 35 and 37
character strings in.

This patch creates and equivalent is_int_like function. If the server_id
is neither uuid_like nor int_like, we throw the InstanceNotFound exception
early. This also saves us a trip to the database in these cases.

Make the is_int_like a little more robust, and don't succeed on floats.

Fixes bug #1100253

Change-Id: If4ae8005fd33a23ac50a6408ecd5933a2ff6425c
"}, {'created': '2013-01-16 23:34:12.000000000', 'message': "enforce server_id can only be uuid or int

the get() function takes an arbitrary id coming from the rest url
for the server. In our current code it checks if this is a proper uuid
and sends it down the uuid path, everything else gets dispatched to
the version that selects by integer id. This means that arbitrary
garbage fuzzed server ids will get sent down the int path, all the way
to the database.

In postgresql, where the db is strongly typed, this causes a type error.
This error was found by tempest nightly runs where we send some 35 and 37
character strings in.

This patch creates and equivalent is_int_like function. If the server_id
is neither uuid_like nor int_like, we throw the InstanceNotFound exception
early. This also saves us a trip to the database in these cases.

Make the is_int_like a little more robust, and don't succeed on floats

Once more with feeling, to let us actually use is_int_like on ints, not
just strings.

Fixes bug #1100253

Change-Id: If4ae8005fd33a23ac50a6408ecd5933a2ff6425c
"}]
commit_message:
enforce server_id can only be uuid or int

the get() function takes an arbitrary id coming from the rest url
for the server. In our current code it checks if this is a proper uuid
and sends it down the uuid path, everything else gets dispatched to
the version that selects by integer id. This means that arbitrary
garbage fuzzed server ids will get sent down the int path, all the way
to the database.

In postgresql, where the db is strongly typed, this causes a type error.
This error was found by tempest nightly runs where we send some 35 and 37
character strings in.

This patch creates and equivalent is_int_like function. If the server_id
is neither uuid_like nor int_like, we throw the InstanceNotFound exception
early. This also saves us a trip to the database in these cases.

Make the is_int_like a little more robust, and don't succeed on floats

Once more with feeling, to let us actually use is_int_like on ints, not
just strings.

Fixes bug #1100253

Change-Id: If4ae8005fd33a23ac50a6408ecd5933a2ff6425c

commit_message:
Move iscsi flags back to driver.py

During the lvm class create the iscsi flags were moved.
This is NOT correct, the flags belong with the ISCSI class
and should have been left in driver.py where ISCSIDriver
is defined.

Moving these breaks the inheritance structure for all those that
inherit from ISCSIDriver.

Change-Id: I1fda9158d9f8f01005875b87265d2dd87bcbc67f

'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-17 09:21:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

What version of libvirt do you have where you see this behaviour so behaviour ? The libvirt getCapabilities() method has been able to cache the data it gets back from QEMU for quite a while now, so it only re-queries QEMU if it has changed. So I don't think Nova should need to be caching it too.

I agree with the change to use getLibVersion to test the conncetion though."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-17 09:22:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2013-01-17 10:07:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Well the slow getCapabilities is obviously in the wild.
I suggest we cache in nova to avoid it and comment
to remove the cache when we require libvirt >= x.x.x'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-17 10:12:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'd prefer to get greater clarity from the bug reporter on the versions involved before changing this. It also isn't clear to me from that bug report that caching of capabilities is what brings us the big win. It seems more like it is the change to use getLibVersion that is the performance win here."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-17 10:18:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Oh and also note that the getCapabilities() call is not the only thing that causes libvirt to run QEMU to parse features. The actual VM start APIs do that multiple times too and the bug report hasn't actually shown which APIs calls are responsible for the QEMU processes being run."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-17 12:41:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm completely fine moving forward on this, as this will have a huge impact on the ci gate."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-01-17 16:06:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

(1 inline comment)

If this fails to merge, can you fix the commit message spelling thing? I'm seeing my therapist later today..."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-17 16:06:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-17 16:26:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I really thing we should *not* merge this until we have clearly identified the root cause. In 6 months time when we wonder whether this hack is still needed or not, we have no information on which to make a sensible decision.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:30:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Caching getCapabilities saves ~2 seconds in boot time on my devstack install (10 -> 8). I susupect it saves significant time in the periodic tasks as well as other commands.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-01-17 18:42:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-17 00:58:10.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Optimize test_connection and capabilities

The getCapabilities call can be very slow so it is not a good choice
for testing the libvirt connection. This patch switches to
getLibVersion and also caches the result of getCapabilities so it
doesn't need to be requested every time. Note that this means that
nova-compute will need to be restarted if the capaabilities of the
host changes. This is an acceptable risk because capabilities
changes should be very rare and nova-compute should be restarted
if libvirt is restarted or reinstalled.

This simple change lowers boot time in my devstack install from
22 seconds down to 8 seconds!

Fixes bug 1100446

Change-Id: I1b5072a906b19c6130957cf255e8d35b20990828
"}, {'created': '2013-01-17 03:09:29.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Optimize test_connection and capabilities

The getCapabilities call can be very slow so it is not a good choice
for testing the libvirt connection. This patch switches to
getLibVersion and also caches the result of getCapabilities so it
doesn't need to be requested every time. Note that this means that
nova-compute will need to be restarted if the capaabilities of the
host changes. This is an acceptable risk because capabilities
changes should be very rare and nova-compute should be restarted
if libvirt is restarted or reinstalled.

This simple change lowers boot time in my devstack install from
22 seconds down to 8 seconds!

Fixes bug 1100446

Change-Id: I1b5072a906b19c6130957cf255e8d35b20990828
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Optimize test_connection and capabilities

The getCapabilities call can be very slow so it is not a good choice
for testing the libvirt connection. This patch switches to
getLibVersion and also caches the result of getCapabilities so it
doesn't need to be requested every time. Note that this means that
nova-compute will need to be restarted if the capaabilities of the
host changes. This is an acceptable risk because capabilities
changes should be very rare and nova-compute should be restarted
if libvirt is restarted or reinstalled.

This simple change lowers boot time in my devstack install from
22 seconds down to 8 seconds!

Fixes bug 1100446

Change-Id: I1b5072a906b19c6130957cf255e8d35b20990828

commit_message:
Provide atomic database access nvp plugin

* This patch ensures that if multiple queries are done against the
  database they are atomic.
* Removes outdated doc string comments.
* Changes update_network so that it doesn't update the network name in nvp
  since the name is retreved from the database.
* Fixes get_network to return the correct status from nvp. Previously,
  it was always returning ACTIVE.
Fixes bug 1097990

Change-Id: Ie3eb67c98dcb36b18cbef2e0905b59eba48ca81d

being called, especially for POST, where the action is in the body.

Change-Id: Ief14186b94e321d97575ee25e3507d3fc0178de6
'}, {'created': '2013-01-15 21:42:16.000000000', 'message': 'Make nova-api logs more useful

The current logs make it hard to identify what API command is actually
being called, especially for POST, where the action is in the body.

commit_message:
Make nova-api logs more useful

The current logs make it hard to identify what API command is actually
being called, especially for POST, where the action is in the body.

* Whenever there is body, log it (info level)
* Log what function the API command maps to (debug level)

Change-Id: Ief14186b94e321d97575ee25e3507d3fc0178de6

commit_message:
Fix downgrade revision to make db migration linear

Fixes bug 1100767

The recent commit 7999282 creates db migration branches.
The migration timeline should be linear and this commit fixes it.

Change-Id: I94e1088352112e8c6ec989a54df83e61797b38c5

commit_message:
Avoid cinder calls, when cinder is unavailable

When a volume service is not available, then a cinder client can not
be created. This patch skips the calls, so that dashboard doesn't
break any more.

This is a backport to Folsom release, as this turned out to be a major
issue.
Fixes bug 1084137

Change-Id: I8f2f8b0b131b4bb5319d74f6da48671f146d7e00

commit_message:
Allows identity endpoint to be specified as URI

Deprecates the piecemeal identity URL buildup and
replaces with a simple uri configuration setting.
Gets rid of the /tokens path stuff that was not
necessary to have in configuration file.

Change-Id: I5e80177073f756781f813438d054fede2d6334a3

Adds setting to disable SSL cert validation

* Breakout of prior large patchset. This patch only adds the
  configurability of SSL cert validation in all the clients.

Change-Id: I48385eabd617d19705f3f2bff4820566547be56d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-17 17:37:26.000000000', 'message': "heat engine : watchrule don't run rule for every SampleCount

We should not be triggering a run_rule (which is an alarm action)
for every datapoint when the SampleCount statistic is specified,
otherwise e.g IHA instances get replaced every heartbeat signal!
run_rule should only be called in response to a rule evaluate(),
or an explicit override via set_watch_state()

ref bug 1100719

Change-Id: I91b144f24b542f48aa7fa98d8d8c404479e13483
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
heat engine : watchrule don't run rule for every SampleCount

We should not be triggering a run_rule (which is an alarm action)
for every datapoint when the SampleCount statistic is specified,
otherwise e.g IHA instances get replaced every heartbeat signal!
run_rule should only be called in response to a rule evaluate(),
or an explicit override via set_watch_state()

ref bug 1100719

Change-Id: I91b144f24b542f48aa7fa98d8d8c404479e13483
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-15 19:04:03.000000000', 'message': 'Move compute node operations to conductor

This adds the following operations to conductor:

  compute_node_create()
  compute_node_update()

It also makes resource_tracker use them instead of making direct
calls to the database.

Further, it introduces a convert_datetimes() helper to the db api,
which can be used internally to convert ISO time strings back to
datetimes, so that we're getting them over the RPC wire. This
should be used in other places in the future to fix similar
situations and avoid one-off conversions in random places.

Note that the backref'd service object in the ComputeNode object
seems to cause trouble after making the RPC trip. Since the
resource tracker explicitly uses the service_id field to maintain
the linkage instead, I expect there is some subtle detail about
why this is important. Perhaps related to the fact that the
resource tracker uses the entire object as the "values" to update.
This patch dumps the service field from the values to update
before calling the database

This removes the last direct database call from resource tracker,
and thus the db import.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

Change-Id: I49c0bb30e7dd46d6f68550ebb644381961a0867f
'}, {'created': '2013-01-15 20:01:36.000000000', 'message': 'Move compute node operations to conductor

commit_message:
Move compute node operations to conductor

This adds the following operations to conductor:

  compute_node_create()
  compute_node_update()

It also makes resource_tracker use them instead of making direct
calls to the database.

Further, it introduces a convert_datetimes() helper to the db api,
which can be used internally to convert ISO time strings back to
datetimes, so that we're getting them over the RPC wire. This
should be used in other places in the future to fix similar
situations and avoid one-off conversions in random places.

This removes the last direct database call from resource tracker,
and thus the db import.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

Change-Id: I49c0bb30e7dd46d6f68550ebb644381961a0867f

We need to have this testcase in tempest .

commit_message:
Object write/read ACL and few security testcases

Adds six tests cases to "test_object_services.py" and one test case
to "test_account_services.py" and these are few security test cases
and which also contains three tests cases to check the object
read/write ACL. This submission also contains required class
modifications in account_client.py and object_client.py. Base.py of
../tests/object_storage has also been modified accordingly to use the
same in respective test scripts.

Change-Id: I88abc7979e8b1ab76e4de41827cc8069fd844dbb
Implements: blueprint add-swift-security-tests

Can you please submit this patch to the stable/folsom branch as well, so that the change will get backported to the Folsom manuals?

See http://wiki.openstack.org/Documentation/HowTo#How_to_a_cherry-pick_a_change_to_a_stable_branch'}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2013-01-17 15:49:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Done https://review.openstack.org/19943

BTW why is this:
#  Change the comment to mention where you cherry-picked from, remove the former Change-ID line

That's the opposite http://wiki.openstack.org/StableBranch#Change-Ids

May I also suggest to change .gitreview on stable/folsom to default to the correct branch like in other projects e.g.
https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/stable/folsom/.gitreview"}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2013-01-17 15:55:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Alan:

I just updated that wiki page to specify the change-id should be the same on cherry picks.

Can you propose an update to the .gitreview file so it defaults to stable/folsom on the stable/folsom branch?'}]

commit_message:
heat templates : IHA enable cfn-hup

The IHA template mentions cfn-hup in several places but doesn't
actually enable it, so do so by adding the config file and crontab
entry

Change-Id: Ie852bba24a57c262a8d813d3b3fc76ba9b5e54b4
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

The HeartbeatFailureAlarm triggers prematurely while the instance is
building, because cfn-init doesn't create the files (hence the

commit_message:
heat templates : fix IHA HeartbeatFailureAlarm during instance build

The HeartbeatFailureAlarm triggers prematurely while the instance is
building, because cfn-init doesn't create the files (hence the
heartbeat cron-job) until after the packges are all installed.
If we make the HeartbeatFailureAlarm depend on the WaitCondition, it
won't be created until the instance is fully built.

fixes bug 1100719

Change-Id: Iae73aa0974a3061f56aa3ee52598687f32c0f19b
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-15 13:54:07.000000000', 'message': 'Relax various version constraints.

The current 3rd-party module requirements for cinder are still from the
nova git import. Usually, having an upper bound for requirements makes
only sense where API-incompatible changes are expected (like WebOb). For
the others it is better the only require a minimum version because
usually distributions differ on the shipped versions of these Python
modules. For instance, openSUSE has newer versions for almost all of
those and running the testsuite there works flawlessly.

Change-Id: I4614a2ea87084f927a557b9fb85dcd10ae9dfeff
'}]
commit_message:
Relax various version constraints.

The current 3rd-party module requirements for cinder are still from the
nova git import. Usually, having an upper bound for requirements makes
only sense where API-incompatible changes are expected (like WebOb). For
the others it is better the only require a minimum version because
usually distributions differ on the shipped versions of these Python
modules. For instance, openSUSE has newer versions for almost all of
those and running the testsuite there works flawlessly.

Change-Id: I4614a2ea87084f927a557b9fb85dcd10ae9dfeff

commit_message:
Add skips for tests when dependency not present

Adds dependent skips for a couple of tests that need MULTI_USER but
currently are executed anyway even if MULTI_USER is not set.

Change-Id: Ibec8d2a8ff6a34a8b341ff947418454704603ec7

commit_message:
heat templates : IHA HeartbeatFailureAlarm should be Ref

cfn-push-stats reference to HeartbeatFailureAlarm should be a
Ref not a hard-coded string, or the engine fails to find the
watch because the name lacks the stack prefix

ref bug 1100719

Change-Id: I0fbec026b883348b674327ae6e097a9452ce375f
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
heat templates : add missing credentials to IHA template

WordPress_Single_Instance_With_IHA lacks credentials so
cfn-push-stats can't authenticate with the cloudwatch api

ref bug 1100719

Change-Id: I218eea927a00b6cef58a4a1ee5d930c57ebb8a2e
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Implement get password for novaclient

This will download and decrypt a base64 encoded encrypted password
from the os-server-password extension. It depends on the user
having openssl installed, but if there is an error of any kind it
will print out the encoded and encrypted password instead.

It also implements clear_password which will delete the password
so it can no longer be retrieved.

Change-Id: I2c4e6c3f03b70dc98d6d339381648a6058f46e21

commit_message:
Add encryption method using an ssh public key.

This is a prerequisite for adding support to xenapi with
a guest agent to support the get-password command.

Related to blueprint get-password

Change-Id: I226ea5ee4fd6e326ccbb39cdf9098925d3f45312

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-17 00:38:51.000000000', 'message': "Better instance fault message when rescheduling.

The old code would use exc_info[0] which is the type of exception, not
the exception itself. This would result in the `message` attribute
always being 'type' and the first-line of details being useless.

The solution is to pass the actual exception object so that `message`
becomes the class-name and the first-line of details becomes the `repr`
of the exception object.

Fixes bug 1100559

Change-Id: Ibaeb5dc5af419de6c98b44aec07bff225b2f9956
"}, {'created': '2013-01-17 03:11:57.000000000', 'message': "Better instance fault message when rescheduling.

The old code would use exc_info[0] which is the type of exception, not
the exception itself. This would result in the `message` attribute
always being 'type' and the first-line of details being useless.

The solution is to pass the actual exception object so that `message`
becomes the class-name and the first-line of details becomes the `repr`
of the exception object.

Fixes bug 1100559

Change-Id: Ibaeb5dc5af419de6c98b44aec07bff225b2f9956
"}]
commit_message:
Better instance fault message when rescheduling.

The old code would use exc_info[0] which is the type of exception, not
the exception itself. This would result in the `message` attribute
always being 'type' and the first-line of details being useless.

The solution is to pass the actual exception object so that `message`
becomes the class-name and the first-line of details becomes the `repr`
of the exception object.

Fixes bug 1100559

Change-Id: Ibaeb5dc5af419de6c98b44aec07bff225b2f9956

commit_message:
Enable the user to enforce validity of the gateway IP

Fixes bug 1096532

A new configuration variable is added to enable the user to indicate
if the gateway should be validated on the subnet. For backward
compatibility this is set as False by default.

Change-Id: Ieadd60a945d34703bfee7576aa3b2ff7da3143d4

commit_message:
Expose a get_spice_console RPC API method

To mirror the existing get_vnc_console RPC API method, expose a
new get_spice_console RPC API method. The only console type
supported currently is 'spice-html5' which is equivalent to
'novnc'

Blueprint: libvirt-spice
Change-Id: Iab9d3dfc3564a122a8cd2b53d34fdcc725bfa29b
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

subject: Add a get_spice_console method to nova.virt.ComputeDriver API

commit_message:
Add a get_spice_console method to nova.virt.ComputeDriver API

To mirror the existing get_vnc_console method, add a new
get_spice_console method to nova.virt.ComputeDriver API.

No attempt is made to wire this up to the RPC API, since at
this time there is no equivalent of novnc or xvpvncproxy to
use with SPICE.

Blueprint: libvirt-spice
Change-Id: I4cf12074b240d6882e46a81783cf20a3d97d4b2a
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

Add nova-spicehtml5proxy helper

Add nova-spicehtml5proxy which provides a websockets proxy,
equivalent to nova-novncproxy

Blueprint: libvirt-spice
Change-Id: I48be78c97bb7dd6635fd4bba476ef22701418ba1
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

Hmm, so this introduces a new pre-req that before was only optional if you ran the console thing or something?'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-16 15:40:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I don't think it hugely changes the situation wrt deps. Arguably it is a bug that websockify was never included as a dep before, because it meant that any devstack install was broken wrt novnc server. So for people using devstack this fixes a bug and doesn't cause them any additional install pain, since websockify is now available via the regular pip install process.  For people deploying from RPMS/Debs, the distro vendor will have taken care of adding a websockify deps in their packages, and splitting the novnc server into a separate package if they wanted it to be optional for users. This is a long winded way of saying that I don't think people will notice, let alone complain, about this addition."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-01-16 16:07:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Pull NovaWebSocketProxy class out of nova-novncproxy binary

To allow sharing of proxy code between nova-novncproxy and
nova-spicehtml5proxy, pull the NovaWebSocketProxy class
out of nova-novncproxy into a new nova/console/websocketproxy.py
file

Adds previously missing websockify dep to pip-requires.

Blueprint: libvirt-spice
Change-Id: If1334256680e7075598f00ce153cf6f021cc720f
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-16 17:48:40.000000000', 'message': "Better handling case where Quantum doesn't provide a 'vif_type' field

In

  commit 4babf7d7e12f35c137148727842f7af28312e858
  Author: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
  Date:   Fri Jan 4 12:22:20 2013 +0000

    Make Quantum plugin fill in the 'bridge' name

We changed libvirt VIF driver to pull 'bridge' out of the
VIF model. This only worked for new Quantum drivers that
provide the 'vif_type' portbinding metadata though. This
patch effectively reverts part of that patch, so we have
a combination of the new & old method for determining
bridge names. The libvirt VIF driver will look at the
network['bridge'] field first, and if missing will fallback
to its previous logic which hardcoded bridge names.

Bug: 1100199
Change-Id: I5fd66b0303159c42bd227e97ddab381b2b67670c
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix fallback when Quantum doesn't provide a 'vif_type'

In

  commit 4babf7d7e12f35c137148727842f7af28312e858
  Author: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
  Date:   Fri Jan 4 12:22:20 2013 +0000

    Make Quantum plugin fill in the 'bridge' name

We changed libvirt VIF driver to pull 'bridge' out of the
VIF model. This only worked for new Quantum drivers that
provide the 'vif_type' portbinding metadata though. This
patch effectively reverts part of that patch, so we have
a combination of the new & old method for determining
bridge names. The libvirt VIF driver will look at the
network['bridge'] field first, and if missing will fallback
to its previous logic which hardcoded bridge names.

Bug: 1100199
Change-Id: I5fd66b0303159c42bd227e97ddab381b2b67670c
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-15 20:41:40.000000000', 'message': 'Remove instance in ERROR state after failed create

If a VM was created but resulted in a nova error, the VM would enter
an error state and not be deleteable via heat delete.  Instead
the VM would persist after the delete operation.

Change-Id: I9135aefdf08aba9551f9290bd072906372583ed1
Fixes: bug #1099634
'}]
commit_message:
Remove instance in ERROR state after failed create

If a VM was created but resulted in a nova error, the VM would enter
an error state and not be deleteable via heat delete.  Instead
the VM would persist after the delete operation.

Change-Id: I9135aefdf08aba9551f9290bd072906372583ed1
Fixes: bug #1099634

commit_message:
ReST API: Clean up exception-handling cruft

Now that we have explicit exception types indicating when a resource is not
found we don't have to rely on knowing which call the error was from.

Change-Id: I54ebce7cb68e551852fd87d51b57b26536cde136
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Prepare the groundwork for more exception types

We have been abusing AttributeError and ValueError rather than raising
exceptions that actually describe the problem. This opens the way for
changes that will allow us to handle a wide variety of specific exceptions.

Change-Id: I05c99601d4e877878195e658908fffa0e126f06c
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Don't inherit from NestedStack

The NestedStack class is intended only to be the implementation of the
AWS::CloudFormation::Stack resource type. Other resources whose internal
implementation uses a nested stack should subclass the abstract
StackResource class.

Change-Id: Ic311c220dbf9bdf539d68f4004c8dc14752e057e
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Move abstract nested stack class to separate file

The class heat.engine.resources.stack.Stack is intended to be an abstract
class which resources that are implemented as nested stacks may inherit
from. Rename it to StackResource and move it to the
heat.engine.stack_resource module, so that other resource modules
(including plugins) may include it without having to also import the
NestedStack class (which implements the AWS::CloudFormation::Stack resource
type).

Change-Id: Ie7c05ec64e1c9632c7a24d96b5d790c9e50b691f
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

security group id if the id was an external id. This patch also now uses
set_override() rather than setting cfg values directly.
Fixes bug 1095864

commit_message:
_validate_security_groups_on_port was not validating external_ids

The function _validate_security_groups_on_port was not validating a ports
security group id if the id was an external id. The unit tests now use
set_override() rather than setting cfg values directly. Lastly, quantum.conf
now has the proxy_mode option exposed.
Fixes bug 1095864

Change-Id: I0ec7f9ed36f1a46156c47a115be936bb41ef75d9

commit_message:
Refactor hyperv plugin and agent.

Remove unused imports.
Add an empty tunnel_sync method so that we can run ovs-quantum-agent
with the hyper-v plugin when we are using vlan networks.

Change-Id: I94b1d0cf188d0a1e03e0948708975594f2615fbf

Build successful

'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-01-17 07:31:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-01-17 07:31:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Mark,
In line 82 of the original code, the getall() of webobs MultiDict (which is request.GET) is implemented as:

https://github.com/Pylons/webob/blob/master/webob/multidict.py
    def getall(self, key):
        """
        Return a list of all values matching the key (may be an empty list)
        """
        result = []
        for k, v in self._items:
            if key == k:
                result.append(v)
        return result


which iterates the entire key, val pair list to find all values for a key.

Therefore line 82 of the original code is actually a nested for loop which also does list appends.

I also think using setdefault() is not efficient but I can't think of another way to do it in liner complexity.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-01-17 07:31:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-17 07:31:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Fixes inefficiency in quantum.api.v2.base._filters

Use iteritems() instead of getall() on request.GET

Fixes bug #1092995

Change-Id: Ic0b5e3d7c7b1ddd072d9fe918ea22a8e9aef9ee4

[{'created': '2013-01-17 06:03:04.000000000', 'message': "Improve upstart scripts for some services:

Improve the upstart scripts for keystone, glance-api, and quantum-api:
  - move installation of upstart scripts from first-boot to image-build time.
  - start services as non-root users.
  - wait until services are listening before exiting from 'start'.

Change-Id: Ia37d9b6c5e592512723b22489bb0f83650671f42
"}]
commit_message:
Improve upstart scripts for some services:

Improve the upstart scripts for keystone, glance-api, and quantum-api:
  - move installation of upstart scripts from first-boot to image-build time.
  - start services as non-root users.
  - wait until services are listening before exiting from 'start'.

Change-Id: Ia37d9b6c5e592512723b22489bb0f83650671f42

Some thoughts! Cheers!'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2012-11-28 22:46:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

If this patch is ok, I'd merge it and start working on a new implementation for the config module! Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2012-11-29 09:29:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2012-12-09 17:41:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

So I tried something like this once, but never quite finished before I got distracted with something else.  I took a different approach tho...

It seems like the main reason you need to pass each daemon and server's conf into the ring is to get the swift_dir and use that as the basis to find the swift_conf path.  I find this interesting because swift_dir started out as a way to define where servers and daemons find the rings. :)

I think i'd like this approach better if the ring's init's used swift_dir directly instead of asking for the whole config blob.  Seems leaky this way.

In my impl I was mainly concerned about having multiple copies of configs/rings for branch based work.  So I defined the SWIFT_CONFFILE env var to point to swift.conf and it would define a swift_dir option in it's DEFAULT section that would inform the constant SWIFT_DIR - which all further default locations would be based on.

This way I could:
export=SWIFT_CONFILE=~/branch1/swift.conf
and
export=SWIFT_CONFILE=~/branch2/swift.conf

and swift-init and company would just sorta know to use the right configs.

I think I had it sort of working...

I'm sorta curious if you have a deploy that really *can't* have the hash_path_suffix defined in /etc/swift/swift.conf or if you're just more generally trying to clean up something that seems like it should be more configurable?

Also you may want to check common.constraints, and probetests - probably lots of other places too.  She's got teeth this one."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2012-12-17 19:22:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I agree with the current "params definition structure" what I don't agree with is the way swift tries to read those params, i.e: "/etc/swift/swift.conf" constant being defined in some .pys or the config file being read in more than one place around swift. All this reduces code's consistency and makes it more difficult to maintain.

That said, I like the approach you were pursuing by defining a global var that can be used to pass the config file, besides the standard args and paths already defined but, I'd also add a centralized (?) configuration management in swift in order to read and retrieve configs from a single module in the coude, i.e: from commons import conf. Many projects out there have been using this pattern for their configs and it has turned out to be a good "standard" too (imho).

So, imagine of having that single configuration module:

* It should have some pre-defined configs (those that are always needed for swift to work)
* It should read the config file and populate itself, or some config object, with the read params and values. (It can get config's path either from a env var, a standard path or a command argument)
* It should validate configs (the validation process could be extended by or "out-sourced" to the command / module being executed)
* It should be available at anytime (maybe with a thread-local cloned version but I would prefer not to do this right now).

This is what I'm proposing and I'd also like to discuss it better with most of the folks since it will require many code to be changed but I consider it necessary, tho.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-01-05 04:44:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

0. Please use a shorter, more concise change title (subject).
1. No need to keep conf in Ring (drop self.conf), AccountController
2. defaulting the argument to validate_configuration is pointless,
   because we don't have external users of it, AFAIK. Class Ring, yes,
   but not this one.
3. Not necessary to add validate_configuration _after_ Ring invocations
   in sync.py, because Ring always validates (even if passed as argument)
4. Smaller surgery may be accomplished by exploiting the fact
   that every invocation of Ring in the tree supplies the ring_name.

Please consider the following patch. Use it if it satisfies your needs,
otherwise please let me know where I made a mistake.
 http://people.redhat.com/zaitcev/tmp/swift-hashsuffix-5-1.diff

If you agree with my changes, please remove FIXMEs before finalizing."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-01-09 09:44:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

in the meantime you could use the WIP status on this review.'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-01-09 12:57:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: No score

Sorry for the delay.

So, Yes, I agree with most of the things you pointed out but:

0. I think we should just pass a conf dict to validate_configuration instead of the path string.
1. With point 3. you meant the validate_configuration inside Ring's __init__, don't you? If so, are we sure conf is already validated? And, It could be useful to add other validations inside that function but I'd prefer just to focus on the conf blueprint.

I'll rebase everything and take your patch. I'll also change the validate_configuration argument in order to accept a conf dict."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-01-09 12:57:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-17 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-17 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
/etc/swift/swift.conf shouldn't be hardcoded, It makes swift fail when config isn't in the standard path

* Added conf keyword to ring
* Moved HASH_PATH_SUFFIX load
* Added validate_configuration call where hash_path is being used
* Fixed some tests

Change-Id: Id36ebc0f538da200dce9c60c356c53ab0e5b67fe

subject: Don't set Content-Length when using web.Response.app_iter.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-12 10:51:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/17923/1/check/gate-glance-merge/3029 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17923/1/check/gate-glance-docs/1200 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17923/1/check/gate-glance-pep8/3134 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17923/1/check/gate-glance-python26/2638 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17923/1/check/gate-glance-python27/2652 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17923/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/21925 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-12-12 17:22:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks - I'll expand the assertions in the related tests to check for the other headers we do expect. Can you replace the body of your commit message with a link to a bug report (that you probably need to create)?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-12-12 17:33:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

There's an assertion in glance/tests/unit/v2/test_image_data_resource.py:TestImageDataSerializer.test_download that checks that Content-Length is '3'. Can you explain how that header is still being set, and if this is expected behavior or not?"}, {'account_id': 4375, 'date': '2012-12-13 10:08:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There is indeed an assertion on Content-Length, which is not part of the headers set after the following line:

  self.serializer.download(response, fixture)
  
But the following call modifies the header set again

  self.assertEqual('ZZZ', response.body)

And adds a Content-Length, which makes the next assertion pass:

  self.assertEqual('3', response.headers['Content-Length'])

You can check that by changing their order. The respective code is:

https://github.com/Pylons/webob/blob/master/webob/response.py#L355

As you can read in the docstring of Response._body_get it is eating up the entire app_iter. This somewhat simulates a non-chunked encoding transfer and that's why (I assume) it's setting Content-Length (which would be ok then). It's also documented here: http://docs.webob.org/en/latest/reference.html#body-app-iter"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-12-14 18:16:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Sascha,

Is this behavior causing some bug? Normally I think of chunked transfer encoding as necessary when the server does not know the length it intends to transmit. Since we do already know the length of the image file, we shouldn't need to bother with chunked transfers.

Does that make sense? Is there something else I'm missing?

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 4375, 'date': '2012-12-18 15:33:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Mark

> Normally I think of chunked transfer encoding as necessary when the server does not know the length it intends to transmit.

CTE can be chosen at will by the server. You're right, it usually does this when the length isn't known or the data (file) is just to large to send in a single response.

> Since we do already know the length of the image file, we shouldn't need to bother with chunked transfers.

We do, as said in the description, we set the iterator on webob.Response, that forces CTE. And it's the right thing to do, images are usually large. But as stated in the review description, it's illegal HTTP to set "Content-Length" when using CTE.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-12-20 17:59:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Large http responses do not imply a need for chunked transfers. Large responses only imply a need for streaming transfers where neither side of the connection holds the whole response in memory at one time. (Which, again, is not the same thing as a chunked transfer.)

I did some digging into the Webob source tree and I think I understand what is going on. The only reason why webob unsets the content-length when app_iter is set is because the developers are assuming that webob set the content-length in the first place during some previous action.

For example, if I do
  response.body = 'Hello, World!'

then behind the scenes, webob is doing
  self.content-length = len('Hello, World!')
 
So when I then subsequently set app_iter, webob must obviously undo the work it did previously. The only reason we are encountering this awkwardness is that it has not occurred to the webob developers that we might wish to control the content-length header ourselves.

Rather than using chunked transfers, I think we must treat content-length exactly the same as you have proposed we treat md5-sum: We should simply assign it *after* assigning the app_iter."}, {'account_id': 4375, 'date': '2013-01-07 15:50:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Patch Set 1:

> Large http responses do not imply a need for chunked transfers.

Correct

> Large responses only imply a need for streaming transfers where neither side of the connection holds the whole response in memory at one time.

It's sufficient if the sender can't hold the full response body in memory.

> (Which, again, is not the same thing as a chunked transfer.)

I guess you're referring to "Using app_iter results into chunked transfer encoding", right? I should rephrase that.

> I did some digging into the Webob source tree and I think I understand what is going on. The only reason why webob unsets the content-length when app_iter is set is because the developers are assuming that webob set the content-length in the first place during some previous action.
>
> For example, if I do
> response.body = 'Hello, World!'
>
> then behind the scenes, webob is doing
> self.content-length = len('Hello, World!')
>
> So when I then subsequently set app_iter, webob must obviously undo the work it did previously. The only reason we are encountering this awkwardness is that it has not occurred to the webob developers that we might wish to control the content-length header ourselves.


Right, because the Response object does this:

  self._app_iter = [body]

The size of "body" is known and the response is sent in one go, thus no CTE is needed (https://github.com/Pylons/webob/blob/master/webob/response.py#L365). However, glance code does this:

  response.app_iter = common.size_checked_iter(...)

However, glance.api.common.size_checked_iter only yields a chunk of data upon each invocation (iteration), which is sent over the wire. Thus setting Content-Length here would violate rfc2616. Another more straightforward example is the usage of WebOb's gzip_app_iter (https://github.com/Pylons/webob/blob/master/webob/response.py#L1270) in Response.encode_content (https://github.com/Pylons/webob/blob/master/webob/response.py#L1270): 

        if lazy:
            self.app_iter = gzip_app_iter(self._app_iter)
            self.content_length = None
        else:
            self.app_iter = list(gzip_app_iter(self._app_iter))
            self.content_length = sum(map(len, self._app_iter))

'Lazy' means CTE, no content-length known, the else case is your "response.body = 'Hello World'" case. So WebOb handles the situation according to the RFC and removes the Content-Length header.

> Rather than using chunked transfers, I think we must treat content-length exactly the same as you have proposed we treat md5-sum: We should simply assign it *after* assigning the app_iter.

Since we are using common.size_checked_iter we are always doing CTE (check with curl), hence we must not set it.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-01-10 00:32:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'm sure I must seem like I'm just trying to be difficult, but please bear with me.

It still seems to me like you are suggesting that whenever we pass an iterator for the response body, we are requiring that CTE be used. But that is not the case.

The behavior here depends entirely on the wsgi server (and in fact, not Webob). For eventlet, which we use, you can see it only uses CTE if Content-Length is missing (https://bitbucket.org/which_linden/eventlet/src/0cbeac9c857358320ddf5e00bef162ef187255e9/eventlet/wsgi.py?at=default#cl-326)

                if 'content-length' not in header_list:
                    if self.request_version == 'HTTP/1.1':
                        use_chunked[0] = True
                        towrite.append('Transfer-Encoding: chunked\r\n')
                    elif 'content-length' not in header_list:
                        # client is 1.0 and therefore must read to EOF
                        self.close_connection = 1

(There are actually multiple heads to that branch, and I'm not sure which one is actually used. However they all show the same logic, with albeit different code.)

Just to make sure I checked with curl on a branch where I moved the "set content-length" step to after the "set app_iter" step. In this case I was saw Content-Length reported correctly and no chunking was used.

I believe my original suggestion still stands. Webob is just being a bit silly by wiping out Content-Length when we set app-iter. As a result, eventlet is using chunked transfer encoding under the hood. If we work around the webob issue by setting the content-length after setting the app_iter, then eventlet does not use a chunked transfer encoding and still happily streams through the response without bothering to buffer everything in memory.

Since we've been pushing around this a bit, I thought I'd go ahead and push up my alternative. See https://review.openstack.org/19350'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-17 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-17 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-12 10:14:57.000000000', 'message': "Don't set Content-Length when using web.Response.app_iter.

Using app_iter results into chunked transfer encoding
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chunked_transfer_encoding), where
Content-Length must not be set
(http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec4.html#sec4.4)

Change-Id: I84f92fcb957e06b46934de2a28b8989f179a965a
"}]
commit_message:
Don't set Content-Length when using web.Response.app_iter.

Using app_iter results into chunked transfer encoding
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chunked_transfer_encoding), where
Content-Length must not be set
(http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec4.html#sec4.4)

Change-Id: I84f92fcb957e06b46934de2a28b8989f179a965a

commit_message:
Refactor get_encoded_zip in cloudpipe.pipelib

 * add generate_vpn_files in cert.rpcapi
 * use cert.rpcapi rather than calling crypto directly
 * change some file modes while generating zip file
 * use use_project_ca in test case

Change-Id: I866fb66be5b74c4e9eb137b785ff142058673196

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-17 03:10:27.000000000', 'message': "Better instance fault message when rescheduling.

The old code would use exc_info[0] which is the type of exception, not
the exception itself. This would result in the `message` attribute
always being 'type' and the first-line of details being useless.

The solution is to pass the actual exception object so that `message`
becomes the class-name and the first-line of details becomes the `repr`
of the exception object.

Fixes bug 1100559

Change-Id: Ibd4365395449cbe91ac89c2d38bad5ff7d032b9e
"}]
commit_message:
Better instance fault message when rescheduling.

The old code would use exc_info[0] which is the type of exception, not
the exception itself. This would result in the `message` attribute
always being 'type' and the first-line of details being useless.

The solution is to pass the actual exception object so that `message`
becomes the class-name and the first-line of details becomes the `repr`
of the exception object.

Fixes bug 1100559

Change-Id: Ibd4365395449cbe91ac89c2d38bad5ff7d032b9e

subject: blueprint amqp-rpc-fast-reply-queue
messages: [{'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-16 23:52:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-16 23:53:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned\n\nThis is a duplicate of Change-Id: Idb09a71472866bd3950f58d4f7f45a3181eb40fc, accidentally produced by not specifying the change ID on the commit.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-16 23:43:38.000000000', 'message': 'blueprint amqp-rpc-fast-reply-queue

For AMQP based RPC, specifically RabbitMQ and Qpid, this change replaces the
dynamically created RPC call reply queue with a single queue that is created
on the first RPC call and used on all subsequent calls. It provides backward
compatibility on the callee side by recognizing downlevel callers and on the
caller side by adding a config option to revert to the old dynamically
created queue based upon the msg_id.

Change-Id: Idaa002621a5f85e32b1e608e237e7d6af1085d25
'}, {'created': '2013-01-16 23:43:38.000000000', 'message': 'blueprint amqp-rpc-fast-reply-queue

For AMQP based RPC, specifically RabbitMQ and Qpid, this change replaces the
dynamically created RPC call reply queue with a single queue that is created
on the first RPC call and used on all subsequent calls. It provides backward
compatibility on the callee side by recognizing downlevel callers and on the
caller side by adding a config option to revert to the old dynamically
created queue based upon the msg_id.

Change-Id: Idaa002621a5f85e32b1e608e237e7d6af1085d25
'}]
commit_message:
blueprint amqp-rpc-fast-reply-queue

For AMQP based RPC, specifically RabbitMQ and Qpid, this change replaces the
dynamically created RPC call reply queue with a single queue that is created
on the first RPC call and used on all subsequent calls. It provides backward
compatibility on the callee side by recognizing downlevel callers and on the
caller side by adding a config option to revert to the old dynamically
created queue based upon the msg_id.

Change-Id: Idaa002621a5f85e32b1e608e237e7d6af1085d25

Add a pool of best hosts to choose a host from. The host pool size is configurable. Setting the pool size to 1 will mimic the current
behavior, which is "best_host = weighed_hosts[0]"

Change-Id: I2afd61acc68cf7b1428e4460fb112484af5864c0
Fixes: bug 1098635
'}]
commit_message:
Select from a pool of hosts

Add a pool of best hosts to choose a host from. The host pool size is configurable. Setting the pool size to 1 will mimic the current
behavior, which is "best_host = weighed_hosts[0]"

Change-Id: I2afd61acc68cf7b1428e4460fb112484af5864c0
Fixes: bug 1098635

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-24 06:28:16.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure datetimes can be properly serialized.

The nova-network manager was returning db models from methods invoked
via rpc.call(). These db models include non-primitive types that can
not be properly serialized (namely datetime objects). Use
to_primitive() to ensure that the data gets serialized properly.

Fix bug: #1089430

Change-Id: I0519e88444b8fcc3af5e43170ea07dd966ccef05
Signed-off-by: zhiyanliu <lzy.dev@gmail.com>'}]
commit_message:
Ensure datetimes can be properly serialized.

The nova-network manager was returning db models from methods invoked
via rpc.call(). These db models include non-primitive types that can
not be properly serialized (namely datetime objects). Use
to_primitive() to ensure that the data gets serialized properly.

Fix bug: #1089430

Change-Id: I0519e88444b8fcc3af5e43170ea07dd966ccef05
Signed-off-by: zhiyanliu <lzy.dev@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add a check for unlimited quotas

This extra check will prevent Horizon to
misunderstand "-1" value when tallying quotas,
setting the "Available" field to inf
instead of 0.

Change-Id: Idfeb9a10b8ce8eea1a39b3d48dffe08d6450fadd
Fixes: bug #1084976
